Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Data Collection on the Performance of Adhesive Anchor Retrofits in Unreinforced Masonry Buildings during the February 2011 Christchurch, New Zealand Earthquake

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award is to collect perishable data from the February 2011 Christchurch, New Zealand earthquake on the performance of unreinforced masonry (URM) structures that had been retrofitted with adhesive anchors. Such anchors are used to connect floor or roof diaphragms to masonry walls or parapets. Wall-to-diaphragm connection retrofit using these anchors is the most common seismic rehabilitation technique used in both the U.S. and New Zealand. The URM building stocks in the United States and New Zealand, including both unretrofitted and retrofitted buildings, share many similarities. Perishable data will be collected from as many of the 59 retrofitted URM buildings in the Christchurch area, as well as from comparable unretrofitted buildings, as is possible during the 28-day duration of the field work. This data will be used for follow-on research of this retrofit strategy for the URM building inventory in the United States.

This activity will expand current understanding of URM building vulnerabilities to earthquake effects. By focusing on the observed performance of URM buildings with adhesive anchor retrofits, the data collected and its analysis will provide enhanced assessment methods for evaluating seismic rehabilitation techniques for URM buildings. The goal is to advance the seismic safety of URM buildings, which are widely constructed in the U.S. and one of the most seismically vulnerable building types. The results of this research will be widely distributed to the earthquake engineering community, including organizations responsible for updating and improving national seismic design provisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A field investigation to collect perishable data concerning the performance of adhesive retrofit anchors in unreinforced brick masonry buildings in Christchurch, New Zealand following the 2010/2011 earthquakes is reported. Retrofit anchors are used to connect roof and floor diaphragms in existing, and sometimes historic, unreinforced masonry buildings to the brick walls. Adhesive anchors allow the anchor to be placed such that it is not seen from the outside, and in that manner they do not alter the appearance of the masonry building.

A total of 170 new adhesive anchors were installed in undamaged exterior façades of loadbearing masonry buildings that were slated for demolition. The anchor installations were tested in tension, and experimental variables included type of adhesive, anchor rod diameter, embedment depth, masonry quality, metal foil sleeve presence, and anchor orientation.

The anchors failed due to masonry cracking or breakout, anchor pullout, anchor yielding or anchor fracture. Embedment depth, anchor diameter, and adhesive strength were found to be beneficial to the maximum force capacity of the anchors, and using metal foil sleeves also helped to increase anchor strength slightly. However, anchors installed in an inclined orientation, as is recommended by FEMA, tended to fail at lower forces than otherwise identical horizontal anchors.

The study demonstrated that approximately one-half of the anchors failed at forces that are below the capacity that is presently expected in typical retrofit anchor for unreinforced masonry buildings in seismic zones. Analysis of the test data also demonstrated that adhesive anchors do not have sufficient ability to deform after yielding, thus precluding them from being designed as ductile connectors. Ductile members and components can be designed even though the seismic forces exceed their yield capacity, as long as the member or component can deform without losing their strength.

The overall impact of this study is to serve as a wake-up call for structural engineers and architects who design retrofits to habilitate existing unreinforced masonry buildings that adhesive anchors might not meeting minimum expectations. The documented extensive damage to unreinforced masonry buildings in Christchurch serves as a stark reminder of the negative potential of this situation. 

The study generated a dataset for adhesive anchors and this dataset is the largest one, and possibly the only one, in the public domain in the US. A formula for estimating the strength of adhesive anchor installations in tension was developed, and the deformation capacity of adhesive anchors was investigated to determine if the anchors could be treated as ductile connectors. The project also expose two US graduate students and two US undergraduate students to the methods for conducting field tests of building structures, as well as the techniques for conducting a reconnaissance of building damage following a disaster.
